newsitem.title: USA: GM hikes dividend, sets $2.5 billion stock buyback.
newsitem.headline: GM hikes dividend, sets $2.5 billion stock buyback.

text.p: General Motors Corp. said Monday its board of directors increased the company's quarterly common stock dividend by 10 cents a share and approved a $2.5 billion stock buyback programme.
GM said the stock repurchases would take place over the next 12 months and at current prices would represent slightly more than 5 percent of the common shares in its core automotive business.

GM shares, which rose sharply last week in anticipation, were off $1.875 at $60.625 following the announcement. Some analysts had predicted a stock buyback plan of up to $5 billion and a dividend increase of as much as 20 cents a share.
The dividend increase on GM's automotive stock raised the quarterly per-share payout to 50 cents from 40 cents previously.

GM also raised the dividend on its Class H shares, which are tied to the performance of its Hughes Electronics Corp. subsidiary, to 25 cents a share from 24 cents. The new dividends on both stocks are payable March 10 to shareholders of record as of Feb. 6.

"We intend to pursue the repurchase programme vigorously," GM Chairman Jack Smith said in a statement. "The decision to announce a $2.5 billion programme at this time is based on our belief that we can execute a programme of this size quickly and with confidence."
Smith said GM will consider additional stock repurchases in the future. The automaker ended 1996 with a cash balance of $17 billion, compared with $10.2 billion at the end of 1995.
